name: 4-methyl-1,1'-biphenyl
Reason: The target compound 4-methyl-1,1'-biphenyl consists of a biphenyl core with two benzene rings joined together, and a methyl group added to one of the phenyl groups. The basic unit biphenyl has a melting point of around 69°C. The methyl group typically increases the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and possible dipole interactions, but in this case, it seems to disrupt the regular packing of the molecules, decreasing the melting point. Having a methyl substituent in the para position also decreases the symmetry of the molecule, contributing to lower interaction with neighboring molecules in the solid state. In the case of biphenyl compounds, the steric hindrance caused by the methyl group situated at the para position to the biphenyl bridge has a considerable influence. Estimating the quantitative effect of the methyl group can be complex, but given the actual melting point, the disruption caused by the methyl group appears to lower the melting point by about 19.5 degrees.
